page.title: 05The Undercliff
page.content: The chief natural feature in this area is the'Undercliff'.The total length is about six miles from Bonchurch through to Niton and in width varies from a quarter to a half a mile.In this area, on the land side it is bounded by cliff sometimes two hundred feet in height and to the sea a secondary cliff which in places gives way to rough broken ground sloping rapidly down to the shore. There are bands of {Gault}along the area and the presence of this clay,known locally as"Blue Slipper",is the main cause of the great landslips that have formed the undercliff.The action too of the sea,wind,rain and frost and numerous springs which occur amongst the rock mean that the coastline has been rapidly eroded.Many properties have been affected by subsidence and some quite seriously in this area recently.
